newsitem.title: TURKEY: Turkish deputies begin censure motion debate.
newsitem.headline: Turkish deputies begin censure motion debate.

text.p: The Turkish parliament began debate on Tuesday of a censure motion brought by the leading opposition party against the country's beleaguered Islamist-led government.

MPs are to vote later in the day on whether to hold a censure vote against Prime Minister Necmettin Erbakan's coalition at the request of the main opposition Motherland Party which cites unequal civil servants' pay rises.

The government has faced mounting pressure after a warning from the military about the rising profile of Islamists under Erbakan's rule and rumblings of discontent from the conservative wing of the alliance.

But there were no immediate signs that the government, with a majority of around six in the 550-seat parliament, would lose the vote. Last week the alliance survived a vote on a censure motion brought by two leftist parties which said the country's secular system was under threat.
MPs were also to vote on whether to launch an inquiry into Justice Minister Sevket Kazan, a close aide of Erbakan and a member of his Welfare Party, over his Islamist activities.

The investigation would look into alleged abuse of his position in remarks he made suggesting members of the liberal Alevi Moslem sect take part in incestuous ceremonies and a visit he made to a Welfare mayor jailed for organising an Islamist protest also attended by Iran's ambassador.
